guide.introduction: In these instructions, I teach you how to make a vibrating little cute buzzing humming beetle robot. This is great for beginners because of the simple circuit and low parts cost.
guide.introduction_rendered:
In these instructions, I teach you how to make a vibrating little cute buzzing humming beetle robot. This is great for beginners because of the simple circuit and low parts cost.

Relevant parts
  • (Optional) Make robot bundle
  • Solar cell, 37x33mm polycrystalline
  • Pager motor
  • Voltage trigger IC, 1381-G
  • Transistor, 2N3904 (”3904”) NPN
  • Transistor, 2N3906 (”3906”) PNP
  • Poster putty or tape
  • Resistor, 2.2k
  • Capacitor, 10 megaFarad
  • Hook-up wire, 24-gauge, red and black, stranded
  • Paper clip
  • (optional) 30 gauge magnet wire
  • (optional) google eyes
Tools
  • Hot Glue gun & hot glue
  • Soldering Iron and rosin core solder.
  • Third-hand tool or helping hands
  • Wire cutter/stripper

parts.notes: (or a motor from the mousey the junkbot project with a bent hook hot glued)
or an LED w/ heat shrink tubing on it as seen in radioshack's solar chariots

steps.title: Building the voltage-triggered Solar Engine control circuit

lines.text: We’ll be freeforming this circuit, which means connecting components together directly, without a board. Parts are easily desoldered and resoldered if there’s a problem.
lines.text_raw: We’ll be freeforming this circuit, which means connecting components together directly, without a board. Parts are easily desoldered and resoldered if there’s a problem.

lines.text: Face the two transistors up with their pins toward each other. Solder the base pin (middle) of the 3904 transistor to the collector pin of the 3906 (the right pin, as you read the printing).
lines.text_raw: Face the two transistors up with their pins toward each other. Solder the base pin (middle) of the 3904 transistor to the collector pin of the 3906 (the right pin, as you read the printing).

lines.text: Use needlenose pliers to gently bend the 3904 emitter pin (left) 90 degrees to the side and its collector (right) 90 degrees up. Bend the 3906 base pin (middle) 90 degrees up and its emitter (left) 90 degrees to the side. Solder the 2.2k resistor from the 3904 collector to the 3906 base.
lines.text_raw: Use needlenose pliers to gently bend the 3904 emitter pin (left) 90 degrees to the side and its collector (right) 90 degrees up. Bend the 3906 base pin (middle) 90 degrees up and its emitter (left) 90 degrees to the side. Solder the 2.2k resistor from the 3904 collector to the 3906 base.

lines.text: Trim excess lead length from previous step. Place the 1381 voltage trigger to the right of the 3906, facing the same way. Solder its Pin 3 (right) to the 3904 emitter and its Pin 1 (left) to the 3906 collector. Finally, arc its Pin 2 (middle) around and solder it to the 3906 emitter (left). There’s your basic circuit, ready for motor and power!
lines.text_raw: Trim excess lead length from previous step. Place the 1381 voltage trigger to the right of the 3906, facing the same way. Solder its Pin 3 (right) to the 3904 emitter and its Pin 1 (left) to the 3906 collector. Finally, arc its Pin 2 (middle) around and solder it to the 3906 emitter (left). There’s your basic circuit, ready for motor and power!

lines.text: Hot glue the pager motor to the non-light-sensing side. Solder the positive/anode lead of the capacitor to the 3906's emitter (left) pin. Then solder the capacitor's negative/cathode to the 3904's emitter (left) pin. Solder the wires to the solar cell, and then solder the red/positive wire to the cap's positive lead. Solder the black/negative wire from the solar cell to the cap's negative wire. Finally, hook up the motor. Solder the red wire to the 3906's emitter. Then solder the black wire to the 3904 collector (right). Done with that!

Then solder the capacitor's negative/cathode to the 3904's emitter (left) pin. Solder the wires to the solar cell, and then solder the red/positive wire to the cap's positive lead. Solder the black/negative wire from the solar cell to the cap's negative wire. Finally, hook up the motor. Solder the red wire to the 3906's emitter. Then solder the black wire to the 3904 collector (right). Done with that!

steps.title: Mount the rest of the components

lines.text: Hot-glue the rest of the components to the other half of the solar cell. Unbend the paper clips so that you just have  thin strips of metal. Bend them at the middle, at a 65-degree angle. Hot-glue one to the motor, and the other one to the small electronics. Make sure it looks similar to a vibrobot.

Bend them at the middle, at a 65-degree angle. Hot-glue one to the motor, and the other one to the small electronics. Make sure it looks similar to a vibrobot.

lines.text: Bend a 5" length of 30-gauge wire in half. Hot glue it to the opposite end where the pager motor is. Hot glue on some google eyes to make it look similar to you. Customize!

lines.text: Now, put the SBB on a flat surface in the sun, or shine a flashlight on the cell. After a little while, the circuit will trigger, the capacitor will dump, and your SBB will take off for a short run. Shine, wait, and repeat.

lines.text: If your BEAMbot doesn’t make you beam, carefully examine all connections, resolder anything that looks weak, and separate any components that might be touching (shorting). It’s a simple circuit, so not much can go wrong besides incorrect connections or bad joins.
